Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth,and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening befor.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon,the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arrivving in London at the very conveniant hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is L22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
The Sea fares are:-
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
To The East.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.

div.head: THE EXTERMINATION OF THE MOSQUITO.
div.p: Although a quarter of a century has passed since malaria was shown by Laveran to be dee to the presence of certain parasites in the blood, it is only within the last decade that the natural history of these organisms has been folly worked ont It is no exaggerate now to say that the life story of a malarial parasite is as well-known to the medical scientist as is that of a well-known politioiar to the general pnblio. Jost as we know tha' the eating of 'messley pork' is the means o' transferring the tape worm from the pig b men, we are equally certain that the oon necting link in carrying malaria, blood worm disease, and yellow fever from men to men i> in each case a special variety of moeqoito. This is one of the few absolutely proven iso's of medical science, demonstrated by the evidences in nature and by actual experiment. The examination of the blood of tho viotim o' ’hese diseases is now a routine practice of the modern-physician. It is possible not only b) the m'orescope to diagnose the form of malarir, but also to estimate to some extent the resist ing power of tho individual thereto. It is alar a well-ascertained faot that one human being oannot infect another exoept through the in- tervention of speoial varieties of morqnitoes.

The life history of the parasite begins and ends in man, unless it becomes the gnest of an intermediary host, the mosquito, where it i» capable of sexual development and multiplica- tion. As man therefore oan only be infected bi the moiquito and tho mosq lito by man, it fol lows that the removal of either of there from any locality moans the extinction of the na'a rial blood worm, and other similar parasites knownand(as yet)nnknown.lt is obvious th»re- foie that thire are two ways by which these diseases may be stamped out: the destruction of tho mosquito or, failing that, the is ilation of all oaseo of malaria. That the former method is practioab'e is shown by the splendid results obtained at Ismailia. A'tbongh authorities, in writing of the prevent'on of anopheles mularia, qnote the examination of the anopheles a'' Ismailia as resulting in the diminution in malarial case*, it is astonishing that other towns in Egypt have not followed the exam- I pie of the Csnal town in exterminating mos- quitoes. Although one knows that all mos- quitoes do not oonvey malaria yet all mos- quitoes are a source of disoomfort, il not actual danger to community.

The mosquito is perhaps one of the easiest of all insects to kill. To successfully attack him in his state of fully-fledged indepen- dence and expect to make much headway against the soourge would be impossible. Fortunately it is extremely easy to kill the mosquito in its early stages of jsxistenoe. In petroleum we have a remedy which never fails when efficiently applied. The larvae of mos- quitoes are air breathers. The inspirator; mechanism is very similar to that of the air- iohaling tube of a submarine. A film of petro- leum in water, their breeding habitat, com- pletely prevent respiration. When sprinkled on water paraffin spreads out into an ex- tremely thin layer, so that for a large area a small quantity is sufficient For large collections of water a gardener's wa- tering can is the best applianoe. Small puddles of stagnant water merely require to have the surfaoe lightly touched with a rag dipped in the oiL The small film of oil neces- sary to destroy the eggs of the mosquito does not affect drinking water for domestio por- pores if the outflow pipe-ia below the surface. There is no possible danger ot fire even though wooden structures are immersed in the water. The film of paraffin required is so thin and evaporates so rapidly that it is impossible to ignite it.

Short ot an organised crusade undertaken by the sanitary authorities of a locality much can be dote by individual initiative and example The filling iu of all stagnant pools, drainage, and similar measures greatly mitigate the pest Fortunately in Egypt the malarial bear- ing mxquito has not such a wide geographical distribution as the blood worm disease-bearing morquito. But other species—and their nan: is leg-'on—are soffioiently objeotionab'.e ana suggestive of possible danger, to justify the adoption of any means calculated to get rid « suoh a pest.

The rOle of insects as the carriers of disease has come to be more extensively reoognised of late years. One writer on sanitation, at present in the Sudan, mentions in the disoussion on the cantos of eoterio fever in the South African Campaign what he tehely terms, "the filthy feet of faecal feeding flies.” Flies have also been oredited with carrying the germs of oon- tagious ophthalmia.Flies are known sometimes to have transferred the miorobas of plague from rats to man. Evidence is also aooumulat- iog daily to shew that Mediterranean fever, which seems to be beooming almost endemic in some of the Egyptian ports, more especially Port Said, is an insect-borne disease, most pro- bably due to a variety of moiquito which can live in brackish water.

The recent epidemio of yellow fever in New Orleans only began to show signs of lessening when the municipality and the inhabitants »operated in instituting a general crusade against the mosquito. The Americans, with characteristic energy, instituted what was known as Mosquito Sunday. Each householder who had oarried out the instructions as to 'umigation in the house and the oovering of ill cisterns and stagnant water with paraffin received a button to shew that he had fulfil- led bis doty in attending to his own premises. It is sometimes argued that it is useless for one householder to destroy tho mosquitoes in the basement or garden of his residence unless bis neighbonra. do likewise. Bat this is a fallacy. Mosquitoes, like sparrows and rooks, have special habitats and hunting gronndf. Thus if one destroys the mosqoitose in any particular house, that plaoe is fur some time qnite free exoept perhaps for the visit of some oo lasional straggler.

Incidentally it may be mentioned that petro- enm is very effectual in driving away other insects. The writer has cleared his premises of a horde of small blaok ants by placiog a ittle paraffin in their breeding and rusticg places. For larger insects, such as oockroaohes, it is necessary to lay down borao'o acid, which tots as a poison.on these creatures. When the remedy for the extermination of the mosqnito is so simple and oheap as to be at he command of every householder, it is a great pity that individual initiative and effort is so united, that full advantage has not yet been aken of the means the soooess of whioh was lemonstnted at Ismailia. At the neighbouring and more important centre, Port Su'd, the ‘jamping-off place’ for so many tourists, the nuisance of the mosquito is nearly as great ts that of the ubiquitous Arab street- vendor. In this town all the local conditions are favorable to the saooessfal extermination >f the morquito. Thj oeopsretioa of ths European residents in the carrying oot of an organised crusade would go far to remove the reputation the town has as a hot-bed for the rearing of mo.'qnitoes. The writer has some- times been astonished that the hotel-keepers seem to make no effort,other than tha provission of mosqnito nets, to proteot their patrons. Al- though tha price of petroleum has lately been increase dowing to the trouble in the Caucasus the small outlay required to sprinkle ths cel- lars, basement", oisterns, and bath-rooms would easily be repaid by ths increased cjmfort to the gnests.

row.cell: Sowing of poppies, cumin, and coriander.
Sugar cane cut for sale. Genub winds prevalent.

div.head: THE RUSSIAN CRISIS. ANOTHER GENERAL STRIKE. CRITICAL SITUATION. BOTH CAPITALS CUT OFF. FOREIGN RESIDENTS LEAVING.
div.p: ( Gazette's Special Service ).
London, November 16.

Private advices received from St Petersburg portray a gloomier position than is shown by the press reports. 90,000 workmen are already on strike. British and other foreign residents are leaving the Capital.

A private telegram received at Alexandria this morning announces that the Russian Government has notified the Powers that all foreigners should be withdrawn,as the Russian authorities are powerless to protect them.
St. Petersburg, November 15.

The council of workmen’s delegates has decided upon another general strike to day, owing to the employers having refused the eight-hoars’ work proposal, but it is intimated that the real object of the strike is largely political. The situation is critical. (Reuter.)
St. Petersburg, November 15.
M. Witte’s Polish proclamation is almost universally condemned throughout Russia. It is pointed out that a timely concession in Finland appeased that country.

The council of workmen’s delegates declared a general strike, beginning at noon, in sympathy with the revolutionists at Kronstadt and in Poland. The strike began punctually in all the great works, and on all the railways radiating from this city, except the line to Moscow. Both capitals are cot off from the rest of Europe. The strike is rapidly becoming general. Fifteen high officials met at M. Witte’s to discuss the proclamation of martial law here.
(Reuter)
Warsaw, November 15.
The police has begun to arrest the prominent Polish leaders.
(Reuter)
St. Petersburg, November 15.
The strike has been resumed in many of the works.
(Havas)

div.head: MUTINY AT VLADIVOSTOK. TOWN IN FLAMES.
div.p: St. Petersburg, November 15.

It is reported here that a mutiny has broken out at Vladivostok. Fierce fighting has taken place between the rioters and the loyalists, soldiers and sailors taking part on either side. A great part of the town is in flames. The mutiny was finally suppressed after a state of war had been declared.
(Reuter)
Vladivostok, November 15.
The mutiny here was due to the discontent of soldiers not sent home.
300 rioters, principally soldiers and sailors, were killed or wounded during the first day of the outbreak.
(Reuter)
Vladivostok, November 15.
The Reservists, who are demanding disbandment, have pillaged the town.
(Havas)

div.head: GREAT BRITAIN AND GREECE. THE KING’S TOAST.
div.p: London, November 15.

At a banquet at Windsor King Edward, in proposing the toast of his health, said that he was glad to receive King George, who had ruled so successfully that Greece was now in a most flourishing condition. The study of the glorious language and history of Ancient Greece in no wise diminishes our sympathy and friendship with the Greece of to-day.
(Reuter)
London, November 15.
The visit of the King of Greece to the City and the lunch at the Guildhall were marked by a hearty popular welcome to the Queen’s brother.
(Reuter)

div.head: ANOTHER BOMB EXPLOSION IN STAMBOUL.
div.p: Constantinople, November 15.
A bomb was thrown at Pera into the carriage of Fehmy Pasha, Chief of the Palace Police, who was unhurt The damage is slight Three Armenians have been arrested on suspicion.
(Reuter)
Constantinople, November 15.
A bomb exploded in the main street of Pera behind the carriage of Fehmy Pasha, but did not injure anybody.
(Havas

div.head: INVENTOR OF TORPEDO DEAD.
div.p: London, November 15.
Mr. J. Whitehead, the torpedo inventor, is dead.
(Reuter)

div.head: H.M.S. ASSISTANCE REFLOATED
div.p: H.M.S. Assistance has been refloated. (R.)

div.head: Beau Rivage.
div.p: The Beau-Rivage Hotel, Ramleh, closed its doors for the season yesterday.

div.head: Stray Dogs.
div.p: Stray and ownerless dogs found in the Khalifa district of Cairo daring the night of Friday will be poisoned by the police.

div.head: The Pilgrimage.
div.p: Up to date 23,977 pilgrims have asked for passports for the pilgrimage to the Holy Places.

div.head: Slave Emancipation.
div.p: The Repression of the Slave Trade Department during the last month gave manumission papers to fourteen Sudanese slaves.

div.head: Aboukir Company.
div.p: Mr. S. Gurney Sheppard has been elected a director of the Aboukir Co. (Ltd.), in place of Mr. Samuel G. Sheppard, deceased.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ARMY.
div.p: The competition for H.E. the Sirdar’s Prize will take place on Tuesday. 5th December, 1905, on the Abbassieh Rifle Range.

div.head: A Change of Religion.
div.p: A great sensation has been aroused at Mellawi by the conversion of the headmaster of the Coptic School there to Islam.

div.head: Ports and Lighthouses Administration.
div.p: The tender submitted by Messrs. Suzzarini and Stienon on the 31st October. 1905; has been accepted for the supply of 3,000 sq. m. of paving stones.

div.head: Mixed Appeal Court.
div.p: Basili Pasha Tadros has been appointed honorary president of the Mixed Appeal Court. The appointment will be officially confirmed at the next Council of Minister.

div.head: Suez Canal.
div.p: On the 12th inst. 13 vessels passed through the Canal, 8 of which were British, 9 German, 2 Austrian, 1 Turkish. The total receipts from the 1st to the 12th inst. were frs. 4,045,331.80,

div.head: Rosetta Municipality.
div.p: It is announced that the Finance Ministry will contribute L.E. 300 per annum to the expenses of the Municipality which is to be instituted at Rosetta.

div.head: German Excavations.
div.p: Dr. Rubinson, the well known German Egyptologist, who vi. its Egypt every winter, will conduct some excavations this winter at Ashmouneen and Elephantine on behalf of the Berlin Museum.

div.head: Sudan Mines.
div.p: Application has been made to the Stock Exchange committee to appoint a special settling day in Sudan Mines, Limited - 40 000 Vendors’ shares of £1 each, folly paid (Nos. 20,001 to 60,000).

div.head: Cairo Tramways.
div.p: As the Public Works Department has decided to asphalt Fagallah street, the Abbassieh trams will follow the route Ataba el Khadra, Mohamed Ali street, Mousky, and Daher from January 1, 1906, till the completion of the asphalting of the above-mentioned street.

div.head: Electric Wire Falls.
div.p: A Syrian, while crossing Fagallah-street, Cairo, at 7.15 p.m., on Tuesday, was struck bv a falling overhead wire and tell insensible. Immediate aid was rendered and it is hoped that he will be saved. Is it quite impossible for guard wires to be provided ?

div.head: Kuttabs.
div.p: The native notables throughout the provinces are showing a praiseworthy keenness in the foundation of new kuttabs. At a meeting of the notables of Shebrakhit it was decided to found 21 kuttabs. At a meeting of the Menoufieh notables it was agreed to make a bequest of 200 feddans for the upkeep of the kuttabs recently created.

div.head: Coastguard Administration,
div.p: Mr. Pascal Bavastro, of the Coastguards Central Bureau, has retired from the service of the Egyptian Government, which he entered in May, 1888. Since then he has been chief cashier, private secretary, and chief of the European Bureau, and his valuable services will be greatly missed. He received the Medjidieh in 1901.

div.head: A Sad Case.
div.p: A young woman of the name of Lettohorn was tried at the Native Assize Court, Cairo, on Tuesday last for having caused the death of her new-born child. The young woman was seduced by her lover, who, on learning that she was about to become a mother, abandoned her. The Court, in considering the extenuating circumstances of the cases, sentenced her to two years’ imprisonment.

div.head: Amateur Theatricals in Cairo.
div.p: Our readers will remember the success that the amateur performance of The Pirates of Penzance met with last season at the Khedivial Opera House, Cairo. We are now informed that a committee is about to be formed to take up the question of staging some comic opera in Cairo for the coming season, the proceeds of which will be distributed among the chief English and American charities.

div.head: A. L. M. & D. S.
div.p: The Alexandria Literary, Musical and Dramatic Society’s season will commence on Monday, December 4, when a lecture will be given on “The Desert of 8inai” by Dr. Marc Armand Ruffer, M.A., M D., C.M.G., president of the Quarantine Board. The lecture will be illustrated by some 50 or 60 lantern slides. It will be remembered that Dr. Ruffer visited the Sinaitio Desert last spring, spending some time in studying the country and taking photographs.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES AFFAIR. PROPOSED ARRANGEMENT.
div.p: The following proposals will be submitted to the creditors of the Sucreries Company at the meeting to be held at 3 p.m. to-day.

1. All creditors other than employes, depositors, purveyors, and holders of obligations and Cronier bills are to abandon 20 per oent of their credit and accept in lieu thereof privileged shares bearing 5 per cent interest.
2. That 800,000 bands are to be issued on mortgage and are to be employed to buy out the shares of the Daira Sugar Corporation, the surplus to form a working fund for the company.
3. The Daira Sugar Corporation renounces 1 per cent, of the annual interest, being the difference between the interest on the present shares and that on the shares to be issued to them on payment.
4. As tor the shareholders, they are to receive one new share for each three original shares which they hold.
Further details as to the arrangement should be made public this afternoon.

div.head: EGYPT’S TRADE. OCTOBER RETURNS.
div.p: The Customs returns for last month are very satisfactory, and both the imports and exports show satisfactory increases on the returns for the previous October. The imports amounted to L.E. 2,504,550 and the exports to LB 1,939,074, being increases respectively of L.E. 381,221 and LE. 128,508 on the returns for the corresponding month last year. The imports for the ten months op to the 31st alt were L.E. 17 221,409, a surplus of LE 1,527,700 on the figures for the same period in 19 4,and the exports amounted to LE. 14,817.247, a decrease of L.E. 717,738 on the figures for 1904.

div.head: AN EGYPTIAN PRINCESS’S FLIGHT.
div.p: According to news just received from Constantinople an Egyptian Princess who used to reside every summer in one of the Prince’s Islands in the sea of Marmara, has suddenly disappeared without a word of warning. It is stated that matrimonial troubles are at the bottom of the matter and that a divorce wilt ensue.

div.head: ROBBERY AT MENOUF.
div.p: The Ministry of the Interior reports that M. Carthalis, a Greek merchant of Alexandria, recently complained that his agent, who bad taken from the post office at Menouf the sum of LE. 1,000 destined for the Ghamamieh ginning factory, was attacked on the way to the factory by Arabs who robbed him of all the money.

The enquiries made by the moudirieh authorities resulted in the discovery of the bag which had contained the LB 1,000, and still contained L.E 893, under the threshold of the sister of one of the members of the gang. During the enquiry the brother, who had been arrested, admitted his participation in the theft and revealed the place where he had bidden L E. 77. The remaining L E. 30 had been spent by the culprits, all of whom have been arrested. They are six in number ; four have confessed and denounced the other two. We wonder how ?

div.head: THE FATAL PIT.
div.p: A native of Karnak, near Luxor, had reason to believe that his house was built over an ancient tomb or some old building, wherein a great treasure was awaiting discovery. He dug a huge pit and succeeded in coming upon an old door, which after some trouble he managed to get open. He entered, but never came out alive. His wife became alarmed at her husband's long absence and at last took a lamp and made her way down the excavation to the dorr. She likewise did not come back. The son and daughter then went in search of their father and mother* and they also disappeared. A native of the same village, finding the house deserted, determined also to go down, and on getting to the door became asphyxiated. The omdeh got to hear of this fatal pit and informed the markez authorities. The bodies of the man and his wife and two children were discovered just inside the door, they evidently having been suffocated by the foul air. The story is told by our vernacular contemporary “A1 Moayad ”

div.head: THE BOURSE LANE
div.p: To The Editor of the Egyptian Gazette.

Sir,—Tho block in Bourae-lane is increasing, and every day this convenient and moat central thoroughfare is becoming more and more eneumbered. The latest addition to the lane is an elaborate bar for the sale of syrups, etc, which takes op a great deal of room. Has the Municipality any right to grant reksas for the occupation of the thoroughfare, to the great inconvenience of the public ?—I am, etc
In A. Hurry.
Alexandria, Nov. 16.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Menes sailed from Malta yesterday afternoon and is due here on Saturday next with passengers, mails and general cargo.
The S.S. Orestes (Westcott and Laurence Lire) left Malta to day and is doe here on the 19th inst, with general cargo from Antwerp and London,

div.head: SALT AND SODA CO. THE MONOPOLY—A DIVIDEND.
div.p: It is stated that the directors of the Salt and Soda Company have come to an arrangement with the Government The company, as a solatium for the abolition of the monopoly. will be granted the concession for six years of all the salt-pits in Egypt.
The board of directors of the company has decided to distribute a dividend at the rate of 4 per cent. for all shares.

div.head: THE DESERT CAMP, HELOUAN.
div.p: Our readers are doubtless aware of the existence of the many open-air institutions in England and on the Continent, it being claimed, with no small degree of reason, that living and Bleeping in the open air is conducive to regaining and maintaining the best conditions of health. Believing, as we do,the correctness of these principles, we are pleased to bo able to announce that an open-air camp on the most up-to-date lines has been erected in the desert at Helouan. The camp has been pitched to the north of the town, adjoining the golf links and race-course, and forms from its delightfully open position and structure an ideal spot for those who may come to Egypt for health sake daring the present winter.

The camp consists of single rooms and a sitting-room combined with sheltered verandahs, eta, comfortably furnished, open at the same time on all Bides to the desert and fitted with every convenience. The whole is lighted by electric light and the hygienic arrangements are on English lines.

There are two golf links (10 and 12 holes), tennis courts, cricket-ground, the miniature rifle range of the H S.C., eta, all within a stone’s throw of the camp. The camp is under the immediate personal supervision and direction of Dr. A. J. M. Bentley, and as only about 15 patients are received, special individual attention, which is so necessary to a successful result, is assured.

div.head: HONOR TO WHOM, &c.
div.p: To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette.

Dear Sir.—Will yon allow me a little space for a word of praise for the prompt and energetic action of Yousbashi Waller and bis staff of firemen, in coping with a fire at Ibrahimieh yesterday ? At about 10.30 a.m. my wife telephoned to me in town that a fire had broken out, as I understood, at home, advising the fire station at the same time. My son and I drove straight out at once and found the house of Mr. Sabatelli, a building partly of lath and plaster and partly of wood, situated about eight yards from ours, in flames, and the Fire Brigade already at work. Not withstanding the light and inflammable nature of the building, after some two hoars of work the fire was extinguished, part of the house and of its contents being saved, and the fire prevented from spreading to the adjoining buildings.—Yours faithfully,
P. Schilizzi.
Ibrahimieh, Nov. 15.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET. Kearslby and Cunningham's Weekly Report.
div.p: Liverpool, November 9.

Egyptian Cotton has been in more extensive demand at advanced prices, the quotation of Brown being raised 1/4 per lb, except Fine, which is 3/15d. In Upper the supply is limited, Good Fair being 2/15d and Fully Good Fair 1/2d dearer; the higher qualities are unchanged.
In Futures a good business has been done, and the following are the closing values :
Nov. 8.19 Jan. 8.8 Mar. 8.6 May. 8,6 Dec. 7.12 Feb. 8.7 Apr. 8.6 June 8.7 July. &7

AMERICAN FUTURES. - The Market this week has displayed great activity, and prices have experienced a considerable advance, being at one time as much as 33 @ 35 points higher than those of last Thursday. This induced free liquidation, and prices had a sharp reaction, but to-day’s dosing values are only 3@ 5 points below the extreme rates touched. Bad Crop reports, with greatly reduced estimates of the yield, coupled with heavy purchases to cover by the “Bears,’’ and well maintained manipulation by the “Bulls” and the withholding of the actual cotton in the South, are amongst the principal causes of this rapid advance, amounting to nearly Id per lb in the last three weeks. The Ginners’ report indicates. a far as one can judge, a yield of about 10 1/2 millions, but the Bureau Report of the Crop, i.e., the condition of the Crop which is to be issued to-morrow, is regarded with greater interest, and will have a very important and immediate effect upon the course of prices. It is impossible to forecast it, but general sentiment is looking for higher prices. We are inclined to think that the serious condition of the Crop is being exaggerated, and that present values discount a great deal.
The following are the closing quotations:— Nov. 6.01 Feb./Mar. 6.12 Jnne/July 6.17
Nov./Dec. 6.01 Mar./Apr. 6.14 July/Ang. 6.19 Dec./Jan. 6.05 Apr./May 6.15 Aug/Sept. — Jan./Feb. 6.09 May/June 6.16

div.head: AMERICAN COTTON.
div.p: Messrs. Collinge Brothers, Liverpool, cable as follows Price hammering New York on increased crop estimates. Advise friends to have no interest for the moment.
Mr. Warton Collinge cables from New York as follows Market weak on increased crop estimates. Price cabling over the South. Expect serious break in cotton market-Personally I think liquidation over.

div.head: THE NEW BRITISH CLUB. LAST NIGHTS MEETING.
div.p: A sufficient number of replies having been received to the provisional committee’s circular , to warrant the formation of the proposed new British Club at Alexandria, a general meeting of those who had signified their intention of joining was held at the Eastern Telegraph Company’s headquarters last night. About sixty gentlemen responded. Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield, R.N..K.C.M.G.,was voted to the chair, and addressed the meeting as fellows:

“The printed circulars sent to yon by the provisional committee will have sufficiently explained the object of our meeting this evening, and the response to these circulars assures ns that oar view as to the demand for a local British club at a low rate of annual subscription was not mistaken. Before proceeding to the business on the agenda, I should like to explain that the subscription was fixed at £ .10 0 per annum, because the committee understood that that is the highest rate within the means of all the members for whose benefit it is proposed to establish the club. This rate of subscription having been made the basis of our appeal to you for the formation of the club, cannot be increased except by a practical unanimous vote of those who have responded in the affirmative, until the club is properly constituted with a committee of management and established rules. As the present number of members at £1.10 per annum is not likely to produce a greater annual revenue than £300 per annum, whilst the annual donations cannot be counted on for more than £100 per annum —making £400 in all—the provisional committee can only recommend for your selection premises whose annual rental will not exceed £200. As regards the furnishing expenses guaranteed by us, the funds at present at the disposal of the committee, or promised,amount to £500. It is obvious that, under such conditions, the club most be started on an economical basis with modest pretensions ; but this need not discourage us in our belief and hope that the club will progress and prove a great boon to those for whose nee it is intended, by enabling them to enjoy one another's society, and become better acquainted, in a home of their own conducted by themselves on strict principles.’’

"We now come” (added the chairman)"to the first item of the agenda, the election of a committee of management, and we have great pleasure in telling you that the Earl of Cromer has done us the honor to accept the presidency of the olnb.” This announcement was received with applause. The meeting then proceeded to the election of two vice-presidents, and unanimously voted in favor of Sir Massie Blomfield and Mr. E. B. Gould, 1.S.0.

A discussion subsequently took place as to the name which the club should bear, and it was found to be the general feeling of the meeting that the club should be known simply as the British Club. This led to some talk regarding the definition of British, much of which was irrelevant, and finally it was agreed to leave the question as to the class of British subjects to be admitted to membership for the committee to decide.

Voting then took place for the members of the committee, the following eleven gentlemen being elected : Messrs. J. Hughes, J. McGregor, W. J. B. Webb, G. Morris, T. F. Donovan, W. P. Hughes, J E. Hewett, P. Leveaux, P. Corfield, J. Davies Bryan and Waddington.

This committee of eleven will, daring the first three years’ existence of the club, act in conjunction with the provisional committee, which has row formed itself into a finance committee. It was felt that this was necessary, on account of the latter's responsibility for the proper expenditure of the donation fund.

Plans and estimates were submitted of various premises in the town suitable for the headquarters of the club. It was stated that the club could not be properly housed at a less rental than £250 per annum, and the committee therefore suggested that the annual subscription should be raised from P T. 150 to P.T. 250, as the former subscription was not considered sufficient to cover the estimated expenditure. A good deal of opposition was shown to this proposal, and it was therefore rejected in favor of a proposal of Mr. Chataway that the smaller sub cription should be given a trial for a year or two, when it would be seen whether it could be continued or other wise. As regards the club premises, the committee were asked to come to an arrangement concerning suitable quarters in the centre of the city.
A vote of thanks to the chairman, and to Mr. Giles and the mess president of the ETC. for the use of the room, brought the proceedings to a close.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL DETENTION. LARGE COMPENSATION CLAIM.
div.p: The recent block in the Suez Canal caused by the sinking of the steamer ‘Chatham,” resulting in considerable delay to vessels using the waterway, is at present creating much controversy in shipping circles.

At the instigation of the Leith Shipowners’ Society, the different steamship associations throughout England have been circularised with a view to joint action against the canal company for detention damage, variously estimated at £80.000 to £100,000 What steps will finally be taken depends, of course, upon the nature of the replies received. The opinion is, however, general that compensation should be paid, although there is a disposition to regard the claims as among those which should first be referred to the protecting and indemnity associations, which, if necessary, could open op negotiations with the company. It is also thought by some that, whilst the agitation may possibly not result in redress for the recent detention, an arrangement might be arrived at in the event of future delay.

This is the first time since the canal was opened that it has been found necessary to blow up a wreck in the fairway, and it may easily be that another thirty-six years will elapse before a second disaster of the kind occurs ; but in the opinion of prominent shipowners, the company can hardly wait till then to apply the lesson. Seeing that over 18,000,0 0 tons gross of shipping pass through the canal every year, they think the time has arrived when the construction of an alternative channel should be seriously entertained.

Meanwhile it is interesting to note that, owing to the obstruction , the traffic receipts of the company for October show an appreciable diminution on the same month in 1904 and 1903, reducing the surplus acquired at the end of September by over a million and a quarter francs. Three hundred and three vessels passed through the canal in October this year as compared with 880 in the corresponding month 1904, and 336 in October 1908, the receipts being 8,900,00fr., 10,270,000fr.t and 9,440,000fr. respectively.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Lord and Lady Waterford have been spending a few days in London at Claridge's Hotel preparing for their winter tour, and have now left London for Cairo. They will go on very shortly to British Bast Africa.
Mr. and Mrs. Henry Bacon have left for Egypt and are arriving by P. & O. steam at Port Said for Cairo in the early days of December. They will take op their residence as usual at Shepheard's Hotel.

Shepheard’s Hotel is filling op rapidly. Already 200 guests are staying there. Last night several dinner parties were given there, among them a banquet of the officers of the Rifle Brigade, covers being laid for 22. The band of the regiment played during dinner.
Mr. Morgan had 11 guests, including Major and Mrs. Spong, Crookshank Pasha and Mrs. Crookshsank, Captain and Mrs. McLean, Mr. and Mrs. Hayter, Mr. and Mrs. Stout, Major Davidson.
Mr. E.V. Bird’s dahabieh Zemet el-Nil left Kasr-el-Nil for Luxor yesterday for a long trip up the Nile.
Count Ma z .i.i has returned to Cairo.
M. Thelier and a party of friends are leaving Cairo shortly for a trip on Messrs. Cook’s private steam dahabieb Oonas.
Dr. Leigh Canney has arrived in Cairo from England and is staying at the Continental Hotel.
The branch of the Credit Lyonnais at Alexandria has lost another high employe in the person of M. Beghian, a funde de ponvoirs of the bank.
Dr. Naguib Khuri has been authorised to follow his profession in Egypt.

div.head: LORD CROMER AND GENERAL GORDON.
div.p: Lord Cromer has addressed the following letter to the "Times’’:
Sir,—My attention has been drawn to the following passage, which oocnrs in Volume II., page 383. of Lord Edmond Fitzmanrioe's "Life of Lord Granville": —

"General Gordon’s commission from the British Government and his instruction,, which he revised himself, direoted him to make the removal of the garrisons Lis immediate and principal care, and to report upon the best means of doing this. On his arrival in Egypt his commission, after a consultation with Nubar Pasha, the Prime Minister, and Sir Evelyn Baring, was modified from one of a merely advisory oharaoter into an executive commission, and be farther accepted a separate commission as Governor-General of the Sudan from the Khedive. Both these steps were taken with the approval of the Government at home; but a calm judgment will not deny that the terms of the original oommission and of the commission as Governor-General were difficult to reconcile altogether with each other; that the latter were of dangerous latitude, and that to these ambiguities most of the subsequent trouble is to be traced."

1 do not ooncurwith the view expressed by Lord Elmond Fitzmaurice in the latter part of this paragraph. My opinion is that neither the instructions issned in London, nor those issued in Cairo, affsoted to any considerable extent the ooarse of subsequent events in the Sudan. The faot, however, that so high an authority as Lord Elmond Fitimanrioe should have expressed the opinion I have quoted above, renders it desirable that the facts con- nected with the iisue of General Gordon's n-troc'iona shoal 1 befiFy and accurately, stated. This, so far as I am aware, has never yet been done.

The original iastructiors issued in London to General Gordon on January 18, 1834, ware that he was "to consider and report npen the best mode of effecting the evacuation of the interior of the Sudan.” These instructions, as Sir Charles Dilke explained at the time in the House of Commons, wore oracticslly drafted by General Gordon himself. It has been very ge- nerally supposed that the initiative in changing those instructions came fromCairo.and that the Government of the day somewhat reluotantly approved of them subsequent to their issue. Some oolour is, indeed, given to this view of the oase from the following passage, which is contained in a despatch addressed to me by Lord Granville on March 28, 1884 : —

"Her Msjssty’s Govornmen t, boaring in mind the exigencies of the case, conourred in theso instructions, which virtually altored General Gordon's commission from one of advice to that of executing, or at least directing, the evacua- tion not only of Khattoum, but of the whole Sudan, and they ware willing that General Gordon should revive the very extended powers conferred upon him by the Khedive to enable him to effect his difficult task. [Egypt Ho. 13 (1884), page 5.]"

The trne facta of the case are, that although 1 fully concurred in the alteration of the in- structions, the proposal to alter them did not emanate from myself, nor, indeed, from any one in Cairo. On page 4 of "Eqrpt No. 2(1884)," the followiog brief despatoh.addreesed to me by Lord Granville on January 22—that is to say, whilst General Gordon was travelling from London to Cairo—is given : —
"I enclose herewith a paper containing some suggestions made by General Gordon aa to the steps which should be taken with regard to the present state of affairs in the Sudan.

“Her Majesty^Government have not suffi- cient local knowledge to enable them to form an opinion aa to the practicability of these suggestions, and I therefore authorise you, aa time is valuable, either immediately to mike the arrangements suggested, or to await Gene- ral Gordon’s arrival and oonsnlt with him as to the aotion to be taken. [Subetanoe telegra- phed.]’’

It will be observed that, although allusion is made to General Gordon’s suggrx’ions, the suggestions themselves were not included in the Parliamentary paper. They were, as a mat- ter of fact, six in nomber. I need here only allnde to two of them.
Tbe first was that theKhedive should israe a deoree 'To the Peoples of the Sudan,” in which the followiog paecage occurred :—

"I have commissioned General Gordon, late Governor General of the Sudan, to proceed there as my representative and to arrange with yon for the evacuation of the country and the withdrawal of my troops. Her Ma- jesty’s Government, being most des roua of your we'fare, have also appointed General Gordon as their commissioner for the same purpose. General Gordon is hereby appointed Governor-General for the time necestary to aooomplirh evacuation."
The second suggestion was that a proclama- tion, si7ned by General Gordon, should )e issned 'To the People) of the Sudan,” in which the following passage occurred :—
“I have accepted the post of Governor-Gt ne- ral of the Sudan."

As, when I received Lord Granville’s aotho risation to aot on General Gordon’s sugges- tions, Ge. eral Gordon himself was about to arrive in Cairo, I delayed aotion until I oonld have the advantage of discussing the matter with him. The result was the issue of the fresh instructions, under, which General Gordon was appointed Governor-General of th* Sudan. It appeared to me at the time that, in view of the telegram dated January 22. I had every right to suppose that her Majesty’> Government agreed to altering General Gor- don’s functions in a sense which woold render them ex ecu tire, and no longer "merely ad- visory."

I also take this opportunity of correcting an error in Lord Edmond Pitxmaorioe’s very interesting work. On page 270, Volome II., it is stated that, on the oocasion of M. de Freyoinet'a resignation in July, 1P82, I "said to M. Raverseaux, the French Consol General in Egypt, on hearing the news, 'Ton are a strange people. . . . Yon do not wait for os to ask yon for something ; you bring it to os yourselves.' ’’

This statement, I understand from a foot- note, is made on the authority of M. Alfred Rambaud. I never made any inch statement as that attributed to me. Indeed, I oould not have done so, for at that time Sir Edward Malet was the diplomatio representative of Great Britain in Bgypt. I was in India, where I oooupied the post of Financial Member of the Govemor-Geoeral's Council. I did not arrive in Cairo to take up the post of Agent and Consol-General until early in September, 1883. I may further observe that at that time M. de Vorges was the French Consul-General in Bgypt The Msrqois de Revereeaox was not appointed until April 20,1891—that is to say, nearly nine years after the remark attributed to me by M. Rimbaud is alleged to have been made.
I have reosived permisa:on from the Secre- tary of State for Foreign Affairs to publish this letter.

div.head: THE AMERICAN INSURANCE. INVESTIGATION.
div.p: New York, Nov. 8.
The Legislative Insurance Investigation Committee to-day resumed its sittings.

Mr. McClintock, actuary of the Mutual Life Insnrancs Company rf New York, in response to Mr. Hughes, counsel for the ciroroittee, who questioned him closely as to how the divideudi wore apportioned, explained that the dividends for 1904 were determined in November, 1903, before the earnings for 1904 were knowo. There was no assumed amount of increase taken into account, and the dividends were arrived at by consideration of the gonera1 ran of business. Asked why the company did not give more dividends, as it oould have afforded to do ao, witness said that the rate was fix’d with due regard to the circnmstanoes ot tho company.
Witness said that but $5,168,698 (£1,033,739) were available in 1901 to pay the amount of 89,830,753 (£1,968,150), the coat of the new business, and the old policy holders paid the balance.

Mr. McClintock submitted a statement showing that the earnings of the oompany for the five years from 1900 to 1901 amounted to 331,238,440 (£3,257, 6*8), and that meanwhile the dividends amounted only to 312,828,883 (£2,5*5,776) Mr. McClintock said that 20 percent, was the ratio in 1304 of expanse to total income of the Mutual Life Insurance Company, and that this was also true of the Equitable and New York Life Insurance Companies, whereas the ratio in the case of smaller companies was ranch lower, being even 13 per cent Forty-nine per oenti was the ratio of expense to the amonot paid to tbe policy holders of the Mutual and New York Compa- nies, while the ratio of the Equitable Com- pany was 43, bot that of smaller oompanies was as low aa 29.

div.head: The Bank Rate.
div.p: The week under review, as regards Stock Exchange doings, can only be described as having been distinctly dull. The transactions in the money market have shown that the Bank rate is still proving effective, and, as was anticipated, no change was made yester- day, the rate remaining at 4%. The Bank ret am for the week shows an inr ease in the reserve of £656,000, making a total of £21,497,000, the proportion of reserve to liabilities having ruon in oonseqnenoe 1)% to 40%. It is now believed that the whole of the £1,000,000 in sovereigns, which left Bombay on the 4th inst and is dne at Port Said next Monday, will oome on to London, the Egyptian demand being satisfied. As against this, however, fresh withdrawals for Constantinople are anticipated, and £200,000 is expeoted to leave here to-dey for the Tarlrish Capital.

div.head: Russian disorders and the Markets.
div.p: The daily reports of farther Rassian disor- ders have had a depressing effeot hero, and although it is thoughbin well-informed quarters that some daylight is to be seen through the gloom and that there are alight signs of an improved state of sflaira, still some time mast ' elapse before matters can settle down and warrant any serions attempt on the part of Continental bankers to reopen negotiations for a farther Rossian loan.

div.head: Gilt-Edged Stocks.
div.p: Consols and other gilt-edged investment stocks seem, to a certain extent, to have cat themselves adrift from the ioflaenoe of Rassian . affairs this past week. From all appearances I it would seem there is not a plentitnde of first-olass securities on offer, and the money released by the repayment by some of the Canadian Government stocks has tended to keep the gilt-edged market firm in consequeice. Consols leave off to-night at 88 3/4.

div.head: Foreign Government Securities.
div.p: There was a report bore yesterday that ; Count Witte had been assassinated, and whilst i not credited the statement did not tend to improve matters in the general market. Ros- sian stocks were lower and close to-night at 89. As regards Japanese, the conversion scheme is still nnder discussion, and it is , believed that, when there are the least signs ol improvement in the outlook, this will be effeoted. Japanese bonds have been influenced by the general doll tendency and close to-night at 96 3/4.

div.head: Rails
div.p: In the market for home rails a good basin ess has again been done. The favor- able Board of Trade retnms have farther emphasised the oontinned prosperity of the country, which, of oonrse, means increased earnings for the railways. The Amsrioan market has been more or leu interfered with owing to the New York Mayoralty eleotion, and aa a result prioes weakened, and some stocks showed a sharp fall. They, however, close to-night at their best.

div.head: Egyptians.
div.p: There hu been more doing in the Egyptian market daring the week. A large advance was recorded in Daira Deferred, which have been booght by good people. The closing price to-night is 111-13 with few sellers about, this being a rise of from four to six points sinoe onr last. The ordinal) shares have also been a good market and have been np to 18 & buyers bat close distinctly easier at 18 1/8.
The iune of the Bank of Abyssinia hu been well reoeived, and the shares have been dealt in at 2} premium. They have gradually sagged away, however, and close to-night at )-] nremiom.
Union Fonciere have been firm at 1} premium, and should improve on this prion. National Banks 'have fluctuated between 26j and 26) and they close at the latter price

There are strong buyers of the last issne at 6 j premium, bnt there are no sellers at anything like this figure. Agricultural Banks are quoted 9| with hardly any bnsinees passing. Delta Land and Investment keep study at 9 J and Delta Light Railway Pref. at 19 }. Kbedivial Mail Stumship Co. have again bun enquired for at 1, bnt there are no eeflers at this price. Egvptian Salt and 8od* have advanced to 1 ] buyers. There is nothing to report regarding the lower-prioed shares.

div.head: Anglo-Egyptian Bank's profits.
div.p: The report of the Anglo-Egyptian Bank for the year ended August 31, is a very satis- factory one and will be welcomed by the shareholders. After providing for all bad debts and contingencies snd deducting ex- pense* there is a net profit of £116,108, to which must be added £15,000 carried forward, making a total profit of £180,V 8. The direc- tors propoee to plaoe £1,608 to tbe staff provi- dent fand, and, after providing for interim dividend at 10 % per annum and a dividend of 16 % per annum, to be paid on Deo. 1, to transfer £80,000 to pension reserve fond, and to oarry £36,000 forward.

div.head: Mining.
div.p: The mining market hu also to an extant been affeoted by events in Russia, and in many of the Sooth Afrioan stooks lower priou have been reoorded. There hu boon little doing in the Egyptian section. Bgyptian Minu are slightly weaker at 13s.8d, but United Afrioans have hardened to 1) bid.
